description: The Douglass-Honors College Community presents... Learn to Crochet l Swap the digital grind for something tangible! Our workshop is designed for students looking to master a new tactile skill while de-stressing. You’ll discover the meditative rhythm of yarn and hook as we guide you through the basics of physical creation. In this hands-on session, we will cover:   The Foundations: Perfecting the Slip Knot and Foundation Chain.    Core Stitches: Mastering the single crochet.    Mindfulness: Using repetitive motion to ground yourself and improve focus.   No experience is required, and all materials are provided. Come keep your hands busy, clear your mind, and leave with your very first handmade project!    *THIS EVENT IS OPEN TO ONLY DOUGLASS-HONORS COLLEGE STUDENTS AND THEIR GUESTS
location: Kathleen W. Ludwig Global Village Living Learning Center
name: Learn to Crochet I: The Basics
organizationNames: Honors College
Academic Programs at Douglass Residential College - DRC

description: Come join us for a welcome-back-to-school Mass followed by a casual social night with snacks, games, and a movie!  Celebrate the beginning of the semester together with prayer, community, and a relaxed evening to unwind. Whether you’re new, returning, or just checking things out, this is a great chance to meet people, reconnect, and enjoy a low-key night with friends. Feel free to bring someone along—can't wait to see ya!

description: RU a new student this semester? Have you heard about Douglass, historically known as the women's college at Rutgers? RU looking for a supportive community that will help you hit the ground running and get the most of your time here? Come check out Douglass where we focus on women's leadership by providing special opportunities for you to build your skills and surround yourself with students and staff who are passionate about social justice and centering women's lived experiences.  Meet new and current Douglass students and staff and hear about the opportunities and experiences that will enhance your college journey. From social events like International Women's Day to internship and research opportunities, Douglass enhances all majors and helps you build your resume and connections. Don't miss food and Douglass swag!! description: The event will feature five wellness stations: a Massage Station with three massage therapists, 15‑minute sign‑up slots, and a private divider‑separated area; a Face Mask Station offering a variety of sheet masks, DIY mask ingredients (honey, avocado, oatmeal), headbands, mirrors, and wet wipes; an Essential Oil Blending Station with roller bottles, carrier oils, a range of essential oils, recipe cards, and labels; an Herbal Tea Tasting area with hot water dispensers, assorted herbal teas, honey, lemon, sugar, and disposable cups; and a Yoga/Meditation Area equipped with yoga mats, calming music, dim lighting or string lights, and guided 15–20 minute meditation sessions offered hourly.
name: Spa Night

description: Knight Connections 2026: R U My Roommate? Looking for a roommate for next year—or just want better vibes in your housing journey? 👀Knight Connections: R U My Roommate? is a fun, low-pressure event designed to help you meet new people, explore what you need in a roommate, and build real connections across Rutgers. Move through interactive stations like Boundary Bingo, Tidy Truth or Dare, Red Flag Room, and the fan-favorite LEGO Flower Exchange 🌸. Along the way, you’ll reflect on lifestyle habits, communication styles, and shared-living expectations—all while earning raffle entries for IKEA prizes, swag, and more. Whether you leave with a potential roommate, a new friend, or just more clarity about what you want, Knight Connections is here to help you start the housing process with confidence (and fun). 🗓 Choose one or both nights to attend:📍 Monday, 1/27 — Druskin Lounge, Honors College (College Ave)📍 Tuesday, 1/28 — Livingston B Reading Room (behind RU Cinema)⏰ 8:00 PM – 10:00 PM (both nights) ✨ Open to first-year, transfer, and returning students✨ Complete stations → earn raffle entries✨ No pressure. No awkwardness. Just connections. You belong here — come see who you might live (and vibe) with next year. 💛
name: Knight Connections: RU My Roommate?
organizationNames: Residence Hall Association (RHA)
Rutgers Residence Life

description: BEAT will take a field trip to NYU Tandon in Brooklyn for a talk will about using data and coding to simulate real and fantasy transit lines. It will be hosted by Sunny Ng, software engineer with the MTA, in addition to the Transit Techies group at NYU Tandon's Center for Urban Science and Progress. One of the featured guests is the developer of the popular game Subway Builder.Where: 370 Jay St, Brooklyn, NY 11201 When: Wednesday, January 28, 2026. Leave New Brunswick station at 4:30 pm, maybe get dinner, arrive at event at 6:30 pm, runs until 8:30 pm, get back to New Brunswick around 10:30 pm (all times are approximate)
name: Field Trip to Transit Techies talk at NYU Tandon
organizationName: Bloustein Enthusiasts and Advocates for Transportation

description: The Douglass-Honors College Community presents... Learn to Crochet II: The DRC Red Pine Granny Square Unplug and get hands-on! Join us for a workshop focused on the art of crochet. You’ll learn to create the DRC Red Pine Granny Square, a textured motif ideal for building a blanket or using it alone as a coaster. This session emphasizes tactile learning, guiding you through the rhythmic and meditative motions of working with yarn and hooks.  Whether you’re a complete novice or an experienced maker, you’ll enjoy the satisfaction of creating something tangible. All materials are provided; just bring your curiosity and prepare to leave with a project you made yourself!

description: Drop-in for an Artful Saturday monthly event hosted by the Center for the Women in the Arts at Douglass and Scarlet Arts RX! Taught by a Scarlet Arts Rx student teaching artist from Rutgers Mason Gross School of the Arts. Free supplies, snacks, and boba provided! Supplies are limited – First come, first served. All skill levels and walk-ins welcome! Foundational art skills you will learn at this event: Printmaking fundamentals (Using stamps, ink, and decorative lettering), Creative brainstorming (Choosing words or phrases for your letters), Intentional design thinking (What colors do you want to use? What feelings do you want to evoke?). This experience counts towards the Douglass Discovery curriculum requirement. description: *registration link will be provided soon*   The Rutgers University Honors College is thrilled to present the 1st Annual Heart & Sole 5K at Buccleuch Park!   The race kicks off at 10:30 AM sharp, so come early to grab your bib and free event t-shirt! Pickup opens at 9:00 AM at the Large Pavilion. Every registrant will also earn a finisher medal as they cross the line!   Stick around afterward for our 11:30 AM Award Ceremony, where top finishers will be recognized with exciting awards.   All registration fees and donations will support the American Heart Association in honor of American Heart Month. Thank you for helping us make a meaningful impact! Registration is capped at 200 participants, so don’t wait—spots will fill fast!   Additionally, Honors College students will be awarded 2 community service hours upon request!
name: Heart & Sole 5K

description: Join the Center for Women in the Arts at Douglass for a workshop led by acclaimed artist Liz Collins! This unique needlepoint workshop invites you to explore the meditative joy of stitching. Collins will guide participants through the myriad of stitches possible within needlepoint and share her distinctive methodology for creating improvisational designs, treating needlepoint as a slow drawing process in response to the grid. Only open to Douglass and Art & Design students. Free supplies and snacks provided! Supplies are limited – First come, first served. All skill levels and forms of stitching are welcome and supported. Please arrive on-time. This experience counts towards the Douglass Discovery curriculum requirement. R3: Career/Discovery/Professional Development/Research. Reminder: To receive DRC curriculum credit, you must complete a reflection survey. *Liz Collins is the 2025-2026 Estelle Lebowitz & Ann Beneduce-Lebowitz Artist-in-Residence. Her solo exhibition, Shapeshifter, is on view through March 13, 2026 in the Mary H. Dana Women Artists Series Galleries at Douglass Libraries. ___ * Image and Media ReleaseBy attending this event, you acknowledge and agree that Rutgers University may photograph, record, or otherwise capture your artwork, image, and/or voice. description: What does it mean to survive—intellectually, politically, ecologically, or aesthetically—in a moment defined by crisis? When uncertainty and chaos prevail, those who endure must bend, not break. They must adapt, redirect, stay fluid. How do figures of water help us think survival not as a static state but as a process: precarious, contingent, always at risk of being swept under? Survival and water: two conceptual forces that converge in literary, philosophical, and political discourses across the German tradition. Whether in the form of biblical floods, rising oceans, or mythic rivers—water stages a sight of duality: It is where life and death, healing and destruction, calmness and acceleration are able to meet in a resistant stream of becoming. To survive—especially “with one’s head above water”—is to inhabit the threshold between endurance and submersion, grasping for breath, clarity, meaning. At the same time, survival carries its own paradoxes: Who survives and at what cost? What kinds of knowledge or expression survive catastrophe, exile, war, or erasure—and which are drowned out? Water leaks across genres and disciplines: as metaphor for time and memory, as site of passage and peril, as resource and threat, as a medium of cleansing, forgetting, or border-policing. Meanwhile, survival speaks equally to historical trauma and everyday precarity, to climate catastrophe and cultural memory, to the bodies that wash ashore and those that remain submerged in the archive. This conference seeks contributions that take up the dual themes of survival and water—literally, figuratively, or formally—as critical frameworks. We welcome engagements with water as metaphor, medium, matter, and menace, and with survival as a philosophical problem, a narrative form, or a historical condition. What does it mean to be in over one’s head—psychically, politically, or ecologically? How might “keeping one’s head above water” register both resistance and exhaustion? How are the concepts of water and survival marshaled by thinkers, writers, artists, or regimes? How do literature, film, and theory reckon with flood, immersion, drowning, or breath? What kinds of bodies are asked to stay afloat, and at what cost? Brief: how do we keep our head above water; how do we survive the current?
name: HEAD ABOVE WATER: Surviving the Current. Rutgers German Graduate Student Conference

description: Embrace the spring groove with the Douglass Arts Club! Join us for an unforgettable Just Dance & Karaoke Night—sing your heart out, show off your moves, and vibe with friends in a lively, music-filled atmosphere. Snacks provided–First come, first served. All skill levels welcome! This experience counts towards the Douglass Discovery curriculum requirement. R3: Career/Discovery/Professional Development/Research. Reminder: To receive DRC curriculum credit, you must complete a reflection survey. ___ * Image and Media Release By attending this event, you acknowledge and agree that Rutgers University may photograph, record, or otherwise capture your artwork, image, and/or voice. You grant Rutgers the unrestricted right to use, reproduce, publish, and distribute these sound, still, or moving images in any medium for educational, promotional, advertising, or other purposes aligned with the University’s mission. All rights to these materials will belong to Rutgers University. Please let our photographer or videographer know if you do not want your image taken at the event.
name: Douglass Arts Club | Just Dance & Karaoke Night
organizationName: Academic Programs at Douglass Residential College - DRC
organizationNames: Academic Programs at Douglass Residential College - DRC
Douglass Arts Club

description: Celebrate the incredible cultures of our commuter community with global bites, music, and interactive fun. Come for the vibes, stay for the culture.
name: Commuter Cultural Fest

description: Every 1st and 3rd Thursday of each month! We start again on 2/5/26!  Join us for a creative space where students can explore self-expression through art. Each session offers guided prompts as well as the freedom to create in your own style and medium—whether drawing, painting, writing, or any other form of artistic expression. This group encourages open dialogue, reflection, and connection while using art as a tool for self-discovery and communication.
name: Let's Talk With Art
organizationName: Counseling, Alcohol and Other Drug Assistance Program & Psychiatric Services (University Department)
organizationNames: Counseling, Alcohol and Other Drug Assistance Program & Psychiatric Services (University Department)
Scarlet Arts Rx (Affiliated with a Mason Gross School of the Arts Department)

description: Enjoy good food, great company, and real conversations. Meet fellow commuters and discover what Rutgers has to offer beyond the classroom.
name: SunnySide Start-Up

description: Day of commemoration and reflection for Holocaust Remembrance day.
name: Yom HaShoah Memorial

description: Celebrate the season with a fun-filled afternoon of games, music, and tasty snacks. Soak up the spring sunshine with your friends and make it a day to remember!
name: Spring Carnival

description: Have you considered exploring the Legal profession? Join the BOLD Center on Friday, April 17th for a trip to Rutgers Law School - Newark! Come meet with admissions, learn tips about the LSAT, meet with faculty and current Law students, and even sit in on a class. Registration closes March 29th, 2026.
name: BOLD Legal Careers Exploration Program: Trip to Rutgers Law School - Newark
organizationName: The BOLD Center at Douglass for Leadership, Career and Personal Development

description: Drop-in for an Artful Saturday monthly event hosted by the Center for the Women in the Arts at Douglass and Scarlet Arts RX! Join us for a Spring painting picnic in Jameson courtyard (rain location: Ludwig Center). Artsy door prizes! Bring a friend and a blanket to sit on (if you have one)! Taught by a Scarlet Arts Rx student teaching artist from Rutgers Mason Gross School of the Arts. Free supplies, snacks, and boba provided! Supplies are limited – First come, first served. All skill levels and walk-ins welcome! Foundational art skills you will learn at this event: Painting and referencing nature, Color theory and color relationships. This experience counts towards the Douglass Discovery curriculum requirement. R3: Career/Discovery/Professional Development/Research.Reminder: To receive DRC curriculum credit, you must complete a reflection survey. ___ * Image and Media Release By attending this event, you acknowledge and agree that Rutgers University may photograph, record, or otherwise capture your artwork, image, and/or voice. You grant Rutgers the unrestricted right to use, reproduce, publish, and distribute these sound, still, or moving images in any medium for educational, promotional, advertising, or other purposes aligned with the University’s mission. All rights to these materials will belong to Rutgers University. Please let our photographer or videographer know if you do not want your image taken at the event.
location: Jameson Courtyard / Schonberg Rm, Ludwig (rain location)
name: Douglass x Scarlet Arts RX | Artful Saturday: Painting Picnic
organizationName: Academic Programs at Douglass Residential College - DRC
organizationNames: Academic Programs at Douglass Residential College - DRC
Scarlet Arts Rx (Affiliated with a Mason Gross School of the Arts Department)

description: Come hang out with the Douglass Arts Club and dive into the art of lino cut stamp making! You’ll learn the basics of carving and designing your own custom stamps—perfect for decorating cards, journals, and more. Supplies and snacks provided! Supplies are limited – First come, first served. All skill levels welcome! This experience counts towards the Douglass Discovery curriculum requirement.
